item.title: Agent-centric learning: from external reward maximization to internal knowledge curation
item.description: arXiv:2507.22255v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The pursuit of general intelligence has traditionally centered on external objectives: an agent's control over its environments or mastery of specific tasks. This external focus, however, can produce specialized agents that lack adaptability. We propose representational empowerment, a new perspective towards a truly agent-centric learning paradigm by moving the locus of control inward. This objective measures an agent's ability to controllably maintain and diversify its own knowledge structures. We posit that the capacity -- to shape one's own understanding -- is an element for achieving better ``preparedness'' distinct from direct environmental influence. Focusing on internal representations as the main substrate for computing empowerment offers a new lens through which to design adaptable intelligent systems.
item.dc:creator: Hanqi Zhou, Fryderyk Mantiuk, David G. Nagy, Charley M. Wu
